page.title: 07Oldest Shop in Cockermouth
page.content: I visited J.B.Banks, General Iron-monger and Locksmith since 1836. I walked into the shop to see all the original shop fittings. There are 173 small wooden drawers full of twisted nails, staples, vine eyes, rivets and washers. Keys are made at one end of the counter. Displayed are some keys over 100 years old. Goods are weighed and sold by the lb. The brass weights range from 1/2 ounce to 28 lbs and stand gleaming beside brass scales. The shop extends to the yard beyond and a well has been discovered. Upstairs is a tinsmith's workshop with workbenches, vices and rows of "cokers", which were nailed to clogs. Banks' Yard has a Doll's Gallery where dolls old and new can be seen. I can buy tools, seeds, camping equipment and look at collections of coins, lanterns and farm implements.
